subject: How to get developers to test - FOR SOFTWARE MANAGERS ONLY!!!
msgSnippet: If you are just a measly developer, please stop reading here and get back to work.  This post is for the hard and conscientious workers who achieved the rank
messageBody:
If you are just a measly developer, please stop reading here and get back to work. This
post is for the hard and conscientious workers who achieved the rank of managers (i.e.
people like your boss). Work hard and smart and, one day, you too might be a manager.

--- Software managers ONLY beyond this point ---

A lot of software managers, even those smart enough to get their teams to practice unit
testing, are often afraid or reluctant to use software metrics to track progress and
compliance.

I can understand lazy and incompetent developers being afraid of having their work
measured objectively. But, for the life of me, I can't imagine why someone with the
superior brains and skills required to rise from a lowly programmer to the position of
manager would not want to use metrics like code coverage, or lines of unit test code, in
performing their sacred duties. Who are these metricophobics? Methinks that they are
just spineless namby pambies who can't handle the truth and are afraid of having to take
decisive management action based on actual facts and figures.

If you are one of those jelly-fish managers who indulges in touchy-feely employee
reviews and gentle feedback based on abstract and highly-subjective criteria, you need to
shape up or get out of software management altogether. We don't need you, and we don't
want you!

How do you shape up? You can start by watching, and learning from, a real software
manager in action (i.e. me).

In the following video, you can see how I use the time-tested C.R.A.P. software metric to
handle a developer who refuses to play by the rules. The C.R.A.P. metric combines code
coverage with cyclomatic complexity to detect overly complex code that is not adequately
tested. Do you want overly complex code without tests in your project? Of course you
don't. Then you better make sure that developers don't get away with it.

Here's the link to the video: http://youtube.com/watch?v=JIASiZQR3nI

Watch it and learn. CAPISCE!

Alberto
